We have requested that the Department of Defense offer the same terms to all AI companies, and we believe all companies should be willing to accept these terms. We strongly hope that the situation can be de-escalated, avoiding legal and governmental action, and that a reasonable agreement can be reached. We will continue to do everything in our power to serve all humanity. The world is a complex, chaotic, and sometimes dangerous place.

Under Altman's post, several X users commented:

  • From non-profit organizations to for-profit companies, and then to the Department of Defense. It all changes so quickly.

  • I can't wait to investigate this deal after I'm elected to Congress in November.

  • So OpenAI went from "We also have bottom lines" to "This is our model on the classified DoW network" in just 12 hours? Anthropico was threatened/blacklisted for adhering to the same principles, but when Sam negotiated, it won everyone's applause for its profound respect for security.

First pretending to be on the same side as the competitor, then immediately throwing itself into the arms of the government, Altman played a really good hand.

Altman's "defection" might be traced back to the early connections between the two tech giants. Amodi, a veteran of the tech industry, rose to prominence early in his career at OpenAI. Later, he and several other OpenAI employees left due to disagreements with Altman. In 2021, Anthropic was launched. Its models and tools have been widely used by the federal government, largely thanks to its partnership with leading cloud service provider Amazon Web Services (AWS). Anthropic initially gained a foothold in the Department of Defense and intelligence agencies through this collaboration. Last July, Anthropic, along with xAI, Google, and OpenAI, secured a $200 million defense contract to support the Pentagon's advancement of AI applications. These two startups are now directly competing for users and enterprise clients through their evolving AI chatbots, agents, and other tools. III. Technology as a Bloodstained Sword In the current conflict between tech giants and the US government, Trump expressed his anger in all caps: "The United States of America will not allow a radical, awakened left-wing company to dictate how our great military fights and wins wars!" Since 2018, the conflict between tech companies and the Pentagon has been ongoing. At that time, employees of Alphabet's Google protested the Pentagon's use of its artificial intelligence to analyze videos taken by drones. Relations subsequently eased, with companies like Amazon and Microsoft vying for defense business, and several CEOs of major tech companies pledging to cooperate with the Trump administration last year. However, with the increasing prevalence of automated systems in the wars in Ukraine and Gaza, the theoretical "killer robots" have raised concerns among human rights and technology activists. Jack Shanahan, who led the Pentagon's algorithmic warfare project "Project Maven," stated that the bolder military actions taken by the US over the past year have exacerbated these concerns. “People may feel more uneasy about the lack of any restrictions, and White House legal approvals could become ‘cover for any actions that could lead to procedural impropriety, civilian casualties, and collateral damage.’” Anthropic’s artificial intelligence technology has already been applied in the intelligence community and armed forces, and it is the first AI company of its kind to process classified information through a supply agreement with cloud service provider Amazon. According to reports from Reuters, the Wall Street Journal, and others, Anthropic’s Claude AI was used by the US military in the raid to capture Maduro in January of this year. Through a collaboration with data analytics company Palantir Technologies, it was integrated into the military’s intelligence and data analysis systems to analyze massive amounts of intelligence data, interpret satellite imagery, support decision-making, and potentially assist in operational deployment planning, but specific details remain classified.

IV. Opinions of Relevant Individuals

  • On Friday evening, an open letter to the Pentagon and Congress, co-signed by several prominent technology and artificial intelligence leaders, began circulating. The signatories included 11 OpenAI employees, including Boaz Barak and William Feng, as well as Waymark CEO Alexander Persky-Sterm. ...> “We firmly believe that the federal government should not retaliate against a private company for refusing to accept contract changes. This sets a dangerous precedent. Punishing an American company that refuses to accept contract modifications sends a clear signal to all American tech companies: either accept whatever the government demands, or face retaliation. The United States has won the AI ​​race because it is committed to free enterprise and the rule of law; to undermine this commitment to punish one company is short-sighted and contrary to national security interests.” Musk stated on his social media platform X that “Anthropic hates Western civilization.” Altman took a different approach, supporting Anthropic’s security safeguards, opposing the government’s “threatening” approach, and working to facilitate a deal between OpenAI and the Pentagon. Saif Khan, who previously served on President Biden’s White House National Security Council, stated that the Department of Defense’s move “is likely the most stringent domestic AI regulation ever enacted by any government.” "It's fair to say they consider Anthropic a greater national security threat than any Chinese AI company, while they haven't listed any Chinese AI company as a supply chain risk." "Targeting Anthropic might grab attention, but ultimately everyone loses." Dean Bauer, a former senior policy advisor on AI to Trump, posted on X: "This is practically an attempt to murder a company. I would never recommend investing in American AI to any investor; I would never recommend starting an AI company in the United States." Deputy Secretary of Defense Emil Michael tweeted a series of messages: "Amodi is a fraud and has a God complex. He's obsessed with personally controlling the U.S. military and is willing to jeopardize our national security." Massachusetts Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren urged hearings on the core of this dispute—the issue of AI power. "Did the Trump administration punish Anthropic because it refused to help with mass surveillance of American communities or to create killer robots? The American people have the right to know what Trump administration officials are planning at the Pentagon." Massachusetts Democratic Senator Ed Markey and Maryland Democratic Senator Chris Van Hollen stated that the Pentagon's "threat to punish an American AI company for refusing to relinquish basic safeguards for the use of its AI models represents a chilling abuse of government power." California Democratic Representative George Whitesides expressed concern that Hegsides' "threat to accelerate security policy changes could push the Department of Defense to conduct broader deployments without adequate safeguards." "The President's directive to halt the use of a leading U.S. artificial intelligence company, coupled with inflammatory rhetoric attacking the company, raises serious concerns about whether national security decisions are driven by prudent analysis or political considerations," said Senator Mark Warner, a senior member of the Senate Intelligence Committee and a Democrat from Virginia, in an emailed press release. Appendix: Anthropic CEO Dario Amody's Statement: "I firmly believe that using artificial intelligence to defend the United States and other democracies, and to defeat our authoritarian adversaries, is a matter of survival. Therefore, Anthropic has proactively deployed our models to the U.S. Department of Defense and intelligence agencies." We are the first cutting-edge AI company to deploy models on classified U.S. government networks, the first to deploy models in national laboratories, and the first to provide customized models for national security clients. Claude models are widely used in mission-critical applications by the U.S. Department of Defense and other national security agencies, such as intelligence analysis, modeling and simulation, operational planning, and cyber warfare. Anthropic has also taken steps to defend America's leadership in AI, even when it went against the company's short-term interests. We forwent hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue to prevent companies from using Claude chips; we stopped cyberattacks attempting to misuse Claude chips; and we advocated for strict export controls on chips to ensure democratic advantages. Anthropic understands that military decisions are made by the U.S. Department of Defense, not private companies. We have never objected to any specific military action, nor have we ever attempted to restrict the use of our technology in any temporary way. However, in a few cases, we believe that AI may undermine rather than defend democratic values. Certain applications have also been far beyond what current technology can safely and reliably perform. Two of these uses have never been included in our contracts with the U.S. Department of Defense, and we believe they should not be now: **Massive Domestic Surveillance.** We support the use of artificial intelligence for legitimate foreign intelligence and counterintelligence missions. However, using these systems for massive domestic surveillance is contrary to democratic values. AI-driven mass surveillance poses a serious and unprecedented risk to our fundamental freedoms. Such surveillance is currently legal only because the law has not kept pace with the rapidly evolving capabilities of AI. For example, under current law, the government can purchase detailed information about U.S. citizens' whereabouts, web browsing history, and social relationships from public sources without a warrant. The intelligence community has acknowledged that this practice raises privacy concerns and faces bipartisan opposition in Congress. Powerful AI can integrate this fragmented, individually harmless data to create a complete picture of anyone's life—automatically and on a massive scale. **Fully Autonomous Weapons.** Partially autonomous weapons, such as those currently used in Ukraine, are crucial for defending democracy. Even fully autonomous weapons (those that automatically select and attack targets without human intervention) could be critical to our national defense. However, the reliability of advanced AI systems is currently insufficient to power fully autonomous weapons. We would never intentionally supply products that would jeopardize the safety of American service members and civilians. We have proactively offered to work directly with the Department of Defense on research and development to improve the reliability of these systems, but they have declined this offer. Furthermore, without proper oversight, fully autonomous weapons cannot be expected to make critical judgments daily like our well-trained professional forces. They require robust safeguards for deployment, which currently do not exist. To the best of our knowledge, these two exceptions have not so far prevented our armed forces from accelerating the adoption and use of our models. The Department of Defense has stated that they will only contract with AI companies that agree to “any legitimate use” and remove security measures in the aforementioned circumstances. They threatened to remove us from their systems if we continued to maintain these security measures; they also threatened to designate us as a “supply chain risk”—a label typically used against U.S. adversaries and never before applied to U.S. companies—and invoke the Defense Production Act to force the removal of these security measures. The latter two threats are contradictory: one views us as a security risk, the other as an integral part of national security. However, these threats do not change our position: we cannot compromise our conscience by complying with their demands. The Department of Defense has the right to choose the contractors best suited to its vision. But given the immense value Anthropic's technology brings to our military, we hope they will reconsider. We strongly desire to continue serving the Department of Defense and our warfighters, provided the two safeguards we requested are in place. If the Department of Defense chooses to terminate its partnership with Anthropic, we will work to ensure a smooth transition to another supplier, avoiding any disruption to ongoing military programs, operations, or other critical missions. We will continue to provide our products for as long as necessary, in accordance with the preferential terms we have proposed. We stand ready to continue our efforts to safeguard U.S. national security.

data.title: Discussion on several issues related to stablecoin payments since the Genius Act
data.description:
The future of yield-generating stablecoins is uncertain, while payments are booming

Since the passage of the Genius Act of 2025.7, yield-generating stablecoins have faced widespread resistance from the banking industry, while payment stablecoins have flourished.

Old payments have become the new hot topic, and agents and stablecoins represent the complex relationship between Fintech & Crypto.

Yield-generating is the past, payments are the present, and AI is the futureThis is a dangerous and easily outdated classification, but it provides us with a historical framework that is easy to understand.

Meta is embracing stablecoins again, Google has formed the AP2 consortium with over 60 companies, and Stripe sees stablecoins and agents as the future. However, PayPal, which already launched $PYUSD, and Coinbase, which proposed the x402 protocol, both saw their stock prices fall. We urgently need to address two issues: first, who is fueling market sentiment in this new payment war; and second, are agents and stablecoins truly the next big thing? This article focuses on the former. The relationship between AI, blockchain, and stablecoins will be discussed later, and the outlook for yield-generating stablecoins will follow after a clearer bill is enacted. The losers eat dust; Fintech is more anxious than Crypto. Crypto has hope, but no future for individuals. US stocks and bonds are going blockchain, BlackRock and WisdomTree are frequently embracing DeFi, and token economics is inevitably heading towards its end. Following Peter Thiel's funding flow, selling off Wise stock and holding onto NeoBroker projects like Trade Republic, or looking at Revolut ($75 billion), Europe's most valuable NeoBank project, reveals a changed valuation logic for Fintech. After more than 20 years of effort, Fintech's attempt to build payment channels independent of banks has failed. Only the ability to retain or convert user funds has value. The anxiety of Fintech companies is far more severe than that of Crypto, after all, "public chain + stablecoin" is a self-contained system, and DeFi is a killer application. Larger: Agents will exponentially increase the number of payments; Stripe founders, the Collison brothers, believe a chain with 1 billion TPS is needed. Newer: Utilizing stablecoins to completely revolutionize the existing payment technology stack represents the biggest technological revolution since the API-first model. To realize this promising future, Fintech not only needs to prove itself superior to Crypto companies, but also faces resistance from the banking industry and internet super platforms. With numerous participants, the situation has become utterly chaotic. Compared to unicorns like Stripe, super platforms like Meta/Google are far larger, with trillions of dollars in market capitalization and billions of users being commonplace. They primarily act as conduits, sharing profits. You could say they see hope in creating stablecoins or payment protocols, or you could say they're leveraging their existing advantages to charge higher tolls. Under the benevolent leadership of Vitalik Buterin, Crypto proactively relinquished its independent hardware layer to the internet, becoming a dependent entity of AWS. Tether and Circle's two-way encirclement: USDT fades into obscurity, entering the third world and surrounding Europe and America; USDC focuses on on-chain development, with compliance merely a protective shield for replacing banks. Blockchain not only bypasses the banking-dominated financial industry, achieving a theoretical minimum for independent existence through the underground economy, but also, in the 10 years of Ethereum's development, has demonstrated overwhelming superiority over TradFi in terms of capital efficiency. Most interestingly, this dominance isn't based on the sheer volume of funds; the combined $236 billion in ETH, $300 billion in stablecoins, and $1.32 trillion in BTC still don't exceed JPMorgan Chase's $2.5 trillion in deposits. The advantage lies in the fact that the banking industry can use alliances to block the continuous attempts of Fintech and PSPs (Payments  service Providers, or third-party payment providers), because you simply cannot bypass the banking industry to handle the electronic flow of US dollars independently. Capitalists can sell their nooses; the "traitors" in the banking industry cannot be absorbed by itself, and Wall Street has no regulatory power. On the one hand, after the 2008 financial crisis, the "too big to fail" banking industry is not popular; on the other hand, the crypto industry may be even more brutal than Wall Street in terms of financial order. The ancient political wisdom of "surrounding three sides and leaving one side open" has been skillfully employed by various bureaucratic systems. A closer look at the regulatory actions following the brilliant legislation reveals that the Fed, OCC, CFTC, and SEC have opened the door wide for payment stablecoins, but at the cost of erasing the foundation for yield-based stablecoins in response to the "deposit outflow" crisis in the banking sector, while simultaneously guiding stablecoins into the existing system.

Since then, the banking industry has accused it of causing deposit outflows from small and community banks. However, the die is cast; CMA-backed MMFs not only offer flexible access but also higher interest rates than bank deposits. Ultimately, it was only when the banking industry was gradually allowed to engage in diversified operations and offer similar MMF products that the deposit outflow was finally stopped. Ironically, large banks ultimately used their scale advantage to seize deposits from smaller banks. Heretics are more dangerous than heretics. For another example, in 2013, when Alipay and WeChat were booming, the US banking industry once again raised the banner of protecting small banks. Of course, the ultimate victims are American Fintech companies like PayPal, which also sowed the seeds of the false narrative that third-party payments rely on banks to disrupt them. But Crypto is different, really, it's different. However, for a considerable period and in a vast region, $USDC and $USDT are not competitors. Simply put, USDC follows the "+stablecoin" logic of DeFi + B2B, while USDT follows the "stablecoin+" narrative of CEX + P2P. Furthermore, apart from Coinbase, the vast majority of CEX liquidity is denominated in USDT. In the financial industry, USDC has become the standard stablecoin, and Circle's CCTP stack, built for it, serves as an entry point for institutions to enter the blockchain. In Argentina and Nigeria, the dollarization of currency is essentially USDT-ization. B2B payments: $226 billion (the primary use case, accounting for 60%, with a year-on-year growth of 733%), representing only 0.01% of the approximately $1.6 trillion in global B2B payments. Global salaries and cross-border remittances: $90 billion (<1% of the global share). Clearing and settlement: $8 billion (<0.01% of the global share). U-Card: $4.5 billion. This data is clearly more realistic in everyday experience. Perhaps the trend of stablecoin adoption is more important; you'll see Fintech actively connecting with banks, but banks will resist stablecoin yields while simultaneously supporting more stablecoins. If you observe Tether's recent actions, the partnership with Lutnik and the launch of USAT are just a cover; the $200 million investment in Whop is more authentic and can be interpreted as buying channel fees from 18 million users, using remittances from the Third World to encircle the First World. Therefore, you'll see that cross-border remittance companies in Latin America ⇄ the US, South Asia ⇄ the Middle East, and Africa ⇄ Europe more commonly support USDT, while Stripe and Huma default to USDC. The underlying nature of the cryptocurrency world is P2P, and Circle's conscious efforts to network with businesses and banks, particularly in the B2B sector, which is widely reported and even touted as a future trend, misinterpret the direction of payment itself. As mentioned earlier, pure transfer, clearing, and aggregation channels have little value; processing volume is ultimately a fixed number, lacking the foundation for a market-dream-like valuation. Everyone needs a graphics card for gaming; at most, 7 billion 5090 tokens could be sold, clearly less than the potential gains from AI being considered the fourth industrial revolution. "Payment is not a SaaS or a function, but rather an AI payment infrastructure similar to Cloudflare, where the distribution network cannot be valued by quantity." This is the story Crypto wants to tell the world: to make stablecoins something beyond payments, allowing money to remain on-chain end-to-end. People are talking about the demise of SaaS and the aging of channel providers, as if decades of Fintech will change hands overnight. Of course, things won't happen that quickly, especially since USDC's adoption by B2B institutions still needs time, and Tether's unilateral promotion of USDT and its aggressive buying of old channels may not necessarily lead to the future. If we're looking to establish a point of observation for the payment story in Crypto, the only useful one is how to handle the relationship between payments and returns. It's very clear now: For returns, they can only remain in on-chain DeFi, like MetaMask U Card's partnership with Aave to bypass the US market and enter the broader consumer system; for payment scale, they need to obtain a banking license from an OCC to issue compliant, non-yielding stablecoins, entering the vast financial derivatives field of the CFTC and SEC. As for BitGo's Asian institutional-grade USD stablecoin $FYUSD and Circle's Euro stablecoin $EURC, they've both chosen to confine themselves to a small corner of the market. The essence of B2B is a pipeline, the essence of C2C is scale, and the essence of B2C is a plugin. Looking at the history of payment stablecoins, the hope of replacing card organizations as a new channel is provided by public chains/L2, but compared to the advantage of Fintech "replacing" banks, it must be a new product with MMF + payment functions, that is, surpassing banks in capital efficiency. Peter Thiel is optimistic about Neobank and Neobroker, while Vitalik is optimistic about ETH-backed yield stablecoins. On this point, Vitalik actually sees it more clearly: if there is no ETH-based yield stablecoin to diversify holding risks, at the very least, one should consider using RWA assets to diversify income sources. In short, lacking payment functionality based on on-chain yields, stablecoins cannot escape the dominance of dollar assets and will ultimately be tamed into the banking industry by OCC. Those willing to sacrifice freedom for security will ultimately gain neither freedom nor security. Here's a second dangerous assessment: existing B2B enterprise use cases based on USDC and cross-border remittance projects incorporating USDT transfers are insufficient to propel payment stablecoins towards global adoption. They only possess temporary significance and will not become major players in the next era.

The phase mission of using revenue as a customer acquisition method has been terminated. Under the obstruction of the banking industry, not only will off-chain be inevitably affected, but after $USDe and $xUSD, on-chain has also been shut down. It is indeed necessary to study the adoption of payments in the real world. However, it's important to note that if you only study payments and ignore yield characteristics, you'll miss the most valuable 50% of this wave. USDT/USDC, using government bond interest rates, has been recruited, and the banking industry has won the third wave, continuing to wield its power with the cheapest demand assets. Conclusion: Following the footsteps of Fintech, we hope Crypto will forge a different future. Four driving forces constitute the new payment war: Stripe and others are frantically embracing new narratives for their IPOs; Meta/Google sees their bargaining power as channel providers; the banking industry wants to retain channel fees and cheap assets; and Tether is investing heavily in payment companies, hoping to surround Circle. Two new narratives are packaged into future visions: stablecoins are seen as the obvious agent payment tool, but no one has ever asked whether agents actually need them. data.title: The Pentagon blacklists Anthropic; nuclear war becomes the focus of contention between the two sides.
data.description:
Author: Ye Huiwen, Wall Street Insights

The Trump administration has officially designated artificial intelligence startup Anthropic as a "national security supply chain risk," completely banning its applications in the federal government and military. This unprecedented rupture stems from fundamental disagreements between the two sides on whether AI should be involved in lethal military decisions such as nuclear war.

US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that **any contractor doing business with the US military must immediately cease commercial activities with Anthropic, and existing services will be phased out within six months. President Trump subsequently publicly pressured the company, stating that if it does not cooperate during the transition period, it will face civil and criminal charges.

This move has caused a major upheaval in Silicon Valley, reshaping the rules of cooperation between tech giants and the US military.

This move has reshaped the rules of cooperation between tech giants and the US military.

For Anthropic, valued at $380 billion and having previously secured approximately $200 million in military contracts, this not only represents a direct commercial loss but also sends a strong signal of compliance risks to the entire AI industry, indicating that the government will not allow companies to erect technological barriers in key defense sectors. As Anthropic faces expulsion, its competitors OpenAI and Musk's xAI are rapidly moving to fill the market vacuum. According to the Wall Street Journal, OpenAI CEO Altman has told employees that they are negotiating a new cooperation agreement with the Pentagon, attempting to find a balance between meeting military needs and maintaining the company's security bottom line. The core of the conflict between the Pentagon and Anthropic lies in the right to apply AI systems in extreme military operations. A serious conflict erupted last month between the two sides during discussions of an extreme nuclear war scenario: whether the military could use Anthropic's Claude AI system to assist in intercepting missiles if the United States were attacked by an intercontinental ballistic missile. Pentagon officials accused Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei of attempting to veto the military's operational decisions. Emil Michael, the Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, publicly criticized Anthropic for prioritizing its own ideology over national security and stressed that large technology companies should never be allowed to determine the outcome of a war. Anthropic strongly refuted the military's accusations, calling their claims about missile interception "completely false." Dario Amodei issued a statement emphasizing that current AI systems lack sufficient reliability to drive autonomous weapons, which would endanger soldiers and civilians. The company adheres to its core principle of refusing to use AI technology for autonomous lethal weapons and domestic mass surveillance. OpenAI and xAI Accelerate Market Vacuum Squeezing Anthropic's exit directly altered the competitive landscape of the AI ​​military market. OpenAI is attempting to offer the military a compromise. Altman told employees that the government was willing to include OpenAI's "red lines" in contracts, allowing the company to build its own "security stack." This means that if the AI ​​refuses to execute instructions that violate security principles, the government will not force it to. Meanwhile, Musk's xAI and its chatbot Grok, with fewer restrictions, have become another more attractive option for the Pentagon and have been approved for use in some top-secret operations. However, according to the Wall Street Journal, citing sources familiar with the matter, several federal agencies, including the General Services Administration (GSA), have issued serious warnings about Grok's security and reliability, expressing concerns that its data bias and vulnerability to manipulation could pose systemic risks. The tech industry faces a reassessment of compliance and investment risks. A Bloomberg analysis points out that Trump's decision will prompt tech companies investing billions of dollars in AI research to reassess the best way to contract with the federal government. Anthropic was previously the only AI system capable of operating in the Pentagon's classified cloud environment, and its Claude Gov tool was favored by defense personnel for its ease of use. The ban represents a significant risk for both the government and businesses. Even more worrying for the market is the potential for coercive measures from the government. Pentagon officials have previously hinted that they might use their government authority to force Anthropic to hand over its technology. Industry experts warn that such extreme policy options will have a chilling effect on the entire industry, causing investors and companies to worry that deep cooperation with the Department of Defense could ultimately lead to the loss of control over core technologies.
